Definition / general

* Majority of cases are caused by *Bartonella henselae* acquired via arthropod vector (cat flea) or inoculation by cat scratch ([Pediatr Infect Dis J 2021;40:S11](34042905))* Cutaneous red papule 3 - 10 days after contact that may become crusted or pustular, with subsequent development of regional lymphadenopathy 1 - 2 weeks later* Histology is characterized by necrotizing stellate abscesses surrounded by palisading histiocytes* Usually resolves spontaneously; rare cases may require treatment with antimicrobial therapy

Essential features

* Typically self limited lymphadenitis caused by *Bartonella henselae* and transmitted by cats* Cutaneous lesion followed by usually localized lymphadenopathy* Lymph node histopathology characterized by necrotizing stellate abscesses surrounded by palisading histiocytes* Organism stains with Warthin-Starry or specific immunohistochemistry; confirmation by serology or PCR

ICD coding

* ICD-10: [A28.1](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/A00-B99/A20-A28/A28-/A28.1) - cat scratch disease

Epidemiology

* Adults or children can be affected but the highest incidence is in children 14 and under ([Emerg Infect Dis 2016;22:1741](27648778))* Considered the most common cause of benign lymphadenopathy in young people ([Ocul Immunol Inflamm 2014;22:148](24107122))* Estimated annual incidence of 4.7/100,000 population ([Emerg Infect Dis 2016;22:1741](27648778))* Incidence is higher in the southern United States and in the winter (thought to possibly be due to holiday adoption of kittens) ([Emerg Infect Dis 2016;22:1741](27648778))

Sites

* Skin: cutaneous red papule or wheal that may become crusted or pustular* Lymph nodes, most commonly upper extremity, followed by cervical and inguinal; patients may have involvement of 1 or multiple lymph node sites ([Pediatr Infect Dis J 2021;40:S11](34042905))* Liver, spleen or bone* Rarely, CNS, eye, hematologic involvement / complications ([Eur J Intern Med 2005;16:610](16314249))* Parinaud oculoglandular syndrome: follicular conjunctivitis and regional lymphadenopathy, possibly caused by direct conjunctival inoculation ([Ocul Immunol Inflamm 2014;22:148](24107122))

Etiology

* Majority of cases are caused by *Bartonella henselae*, harbored by kittens and young cats; transmitted between cats by the cat flea ([Am J Clin Pathol 1994;101:607](8178768))* Up to 100% of cat fleas harbor *Bartonella* and it can also often be detected in cat saliva, blood, skin, claws and feces* Most important risk factors are owning a kitten and being bitten, scratched or licked by a kitten harboring fleas; however, up to 25% of patients with cat scratch disease do not report contact with cats

Diagrams / tables

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodescatscratch_nih01.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1233974/figure/f1/)

Algorithm for cat scratch disease diagnosis

Clinical features

* Cutaneous nonpruritic red papule: 3 - 10 days after contact that may become crusted or pustular ([Ocul Immunol Inflamm 2014;22:148](24107122))* Lymphadenopathy, often of cervical or axillary nodes, develops in 1 - 2 weeks; lymphadenopathy is essentially universal but 85% have involvement of only a single node* May have necrotizing granulomas in liver, spleen or bone* Fever and constitutional symptoms may be present ([Am J Dis Child 1985;139:1124](4061408))* Rare complications in ~10%, including granulomatous conjunctivitis, thrombocytopenic purpura, CNS disease ([Eur J Intern Med 2005;16:610](16314249), [Infect Dis Clin North Am 1987;1:575](3332886), [Am Fam Physician 2011;83:152](21243990))

Diagnosis

* PCR ([J Clin Microbiol 2005;43:3800](16081914))* Serology or immunofluorescence ([Clin Diagn Lab Immunol 2003;10:686](12853405))* Culture is not practical, as *Bartonella* are fastidious organisms that are difficult to culture ([Pediatr Infect Dis J 2021;40:S11](34042905))

Radiology description

* Regional lymphadenopathy* Liver and spleen granulomas

Prognostic factors

* Self limited disease in most; may take 2 - 6 months for lymphadenopathy to regress ([Infect Dis Clin North Am 1987;1:575](3332886))* Immunocompromised patients may present with disseminated disease or other diseases / syndromes associated with *Bartonella*, such as bacillary angiomatosis ([BMJ Case Rep 2021;14:e239932](34257108), [Am J Clin Pathol 2004;121:S71](15298152), [Eur J Clin Microbiol Infect Dis 2021 Apr 12 [Epub ahead of print]](33846874))

Case reports

* 16 year old boy with tender cervical lymphadenopathy ([Arch Pathol Lab Med 2005;129:1065](16048405))* 32 year old HIV infected woman with *B. quintana* and *M. tuberculosis* coinfection ([J Infect 2003;46:244](12799150))* 53 year old man with cat scratch disease encephalopathy ([BMJ Case Rep 2018;2018:bcr2017223647](29507029))* 59 year old heart transplant patient with disseminated cat scratch disease ([Transpl Infect Dis 2017;19](28199763))

Treatment

* Treatment neither required nor recommended for immunocompetent patients / uncomplicated disease ([Antimicrob Agents Chemother 2004;48:1921](15155180))* Antibiotics (doxycycline, rifampin) could be considered if disseminated or complicated disease ([Antimicrob Agents Chemother 2004;48:1921](15155180), [Pediatr Infect Dis J 2021;40:S11](34042905))

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Early: histiocytes and follicular hyperplasia, microabscesses localized adjacent to the thickened capsule ([Am J Clin Pathol 2004;121:S71](15298152))* Intermediate: capsulitis and subcapsular granulomas* Late: necrosis and abscesses, often stellate, surrounded by palisading histiocytes ([Int J Dermatol 1978;17:656](103848))* Paracortical vascular proliferation ([Am J Clin Pathol 2004;121:S71](15298152))* Sinuses are often packed with monocytoid B cells but no epithelioid cells are present ([Am J Clin Pathol 2004;121:S71](15298152))* Small rods may be present with silver stain around small blood vessels and lymphatics; most readily identified early in disease ([Science 1983;221:1403](6612349), [Am J Clin Pathol 2004;121:S71](15298152))* Skin shows dermal necrosis surrounded by histiocytes* Also multinucleated giant cells, lymphocytes and eosinophils* References: [Calif Med 1955;82:25](13230912), [Am Fam Physician 2011;83:152](21243990)

Cytology description

* Similar to histologic features (granulomas, epithelioid histiocytes, neutrophils, necrosis, polymorphous lymphocytes) ([Acta Cytol 1985;29:542](3861042), [Diagn Cytopathol 1996;15:108](8872431))

Positive stains

* [Warthin-Starry](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainswarthin.html) or other silver stains* ***B. henslae*** immunohistochemistry ([Am J Clin Pathol 2009;131:250](19141385))* Combined use of [Warthin-Starry](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainswarthin.html) and IHC may yield higher sensitivity than either alone ([Appl Immunohistochem Mol Morphol 2020;28:781](31913159))

Negative stains

* [Gram stain](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsgramstain.html) has limited utility, as *Bartonella* usually does not stain well ([Am J Clin Pathol 2009;131:250](19141385))

Electron microscopy description

* Extracellular bacteria form small groups within bundles of collagen fibrils* Bacteria are gram negative pleomorphic rods, with thick and homogeneous cell walls ([Am J Clin Pathol 1987;87:739](2438928))

Molecular / cytogenetics description

* Causative organism may be detected by PCR ([J Clin Microbiol 2005;43:3800](16081914))

Sample pathology report

* Cervical lymph node, excision:
  + Necrotizing granulomatous lymphadenitis (see comment)+ Comment: The lymph node architecture is distorted by frequent stellate necrotizing granulomas with occasional multinucleated giant cells. Bacterial structures are identified by both Warthin-Starry stain and immunohistochemistry for *B. henselae*. The overall features are in keeping with cat scratch lymphadenitis, a condition that is generally self limited in immunocompentent patients.

Differential diagnosis

* **Lymphoma**, particularly [classic Hodgkin lymphoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphomanonBclassic.html):
  + May demonstrate granulomatous inflammation but will have Hodgkin / Reed-Sternberg cells and mixed inflammation, including eosinophils and plasma cells* [Sarcoidosis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skinnontumorsarcoidosis.html):
    + Granulomas usually small and tight without suppuration* Other infectious agents capable of causing [granulomatous lymphadenitis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesgranulomatous.html):
      + [Mycobacteriaceae](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesatypicalmycobacteria.html), *[Chlamydia trachomatis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cervixchlamydia.html), [Francisella tularensis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesotherinfections.html#tularemia), [Treponema pallidum](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainstreponemaihc.html)*, **fungi*** [Kikuchi syndrome](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodeskikuchi.html):
        + No neutrophils* [Kimura disease](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodeskimurasdisease.html):
          + Eosinophils predominate, rather than neutrophils
